Einstein was playing a whole different ball game

Okay, I get that Einstein's idea, that one could calculate the mass of an atom by measuring how much Brownian particles move, isn't an accurate way of measuring the mass of an atom and generally shouldn't be used to calculate the mass of an atom; however (in my opinion) you might be able to at least get an idea of the atom's mass. Looking at a bigger picture, we know that water is composed of water molecules (hydrogen monoxide), right? Knowing that water molecules are made up of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, we can assume that if one Brownian particle were to be placed in a container filled with only water and the other to be put in a container filled with only hydrogen, then theoretically speaking the Brownian particle in the water container should show more movement, since the molecules in the water containers have more mass and therefore have more force to inflict upon the Brownian particle. Of course, measuring the mass of an atom based on the movement of a Brownian particle has a high margin of error due to temperature differences, the size and mass of the Brownian particle, the angle at which it the Brownian particle is being hit, (etc.); however in the future I believe that calculating the mass of Brownian particles using this method will be possible, which is why I think Einstein wasn't that crazy for thinking that we can calculate masses using this method. Unfortunately, for now this method isn't very useful for calculating the exact mass of atoms. The only thing it can do that's really important is that it gives us an idea of the atom/molecule's mass and it gives us more indirect evidence that atoms exist.

the only time particles truely "touch" is during annihilation and absorption, but two fundamental particles can never touch and stay that way, as soon as they touch they combine and form a completely different particle from the initial two.

and absoption is just a particle absoring something like a boson, the boson literally dissapears as soon as it touches the particle, and the parent particle gains the extra energy and momentum from the boson.

however, particle annihilation is different from atom fusion.

during atom fusion, the two nucleouses of the atoms fuse together, but the quarks themselves are never actually touching , at all.

the constituens of atoms do not actually touch in fusion either.

all fusion is two atoms melding together, but nothing ever actually touches.


fundamental particles can touch however, they can annihilate into larger particles, but they can never stay "together in touch" , they either annihilate or repell, without touching.

Aye, but now I think everyone is just twisting words here. The particles do bounce of each other because of the electric (Coulomb) force between them. I don't believe that the term "bounce" requires the nuclei of two particles to come into direct contact.
Since Heisenberg's uncertainty principle prevails for atoms we have no certain way of saying if particles are in contact or not, only that their wave-functions overlap. We can measure the scattering though (see Rutherford's experiment).

Actually it's very simple to measure the approximate size/mass of a penguin based on how much an iceberg moves. A penguin jumps off the iceberg. You know its velocity. @worknowful So to answer your question the energy in a black hole is probably is equal to that of went into the black hole and in the same form. So if a black hole took in a star then it would have all the thermal "heat" energy of the star inside of it self along with the luminous "light" energy and all the other types of energy that the star had when it was outside of the black hole. I am just an undergrad math and physics major so i could be wrong but that is my understanding.
@worknowful Light is a form of energy and so is heat but just because they are both forms of energy that does not mean that something that products light products heat as well.

@dude444american although we can not see light looking into a black hole does not that it is not there. Inside a black hole every photon that has ever went toward that black hole is trapped inside of the black hole. If we were to go inside a black hole it would probably be the brightest thing you would ever see do to all the trapped photons. but because something is bright does not mean it is hot.

@MrScillage It's usually known as the 'heat equation' or the 'diffusion equation'. It describes how heat (or other stuff; in this case, little dust motes) spreads out over time. As it's written, it actually describes spreading out in one dimension, as if if the dust motes were constrained to move on a particular line. If there are additional sources of heat (or dust), then you need additional terms to describe the sources.

@MrScillage It's usually known as the 'heat equation' or the 'diffusion equation'. It describes how heat (or other stuff, in this case little dust motes) spreads out over time. And as written it's actually for spreading out in one dimension, so like if the dust motes were constrained to move on a particular line. And there can be other complications if there are additional sources of heat/dust (you need another term describing the source).
